Entry.1: In Arabian Sea. Sighted several vessels going east. Lectures and reading.
Entry.2: Same routine. Was vaccinated in 3 spots on right arm.
Entry.3:
No lectures. Attended both church parades; also "sing song" in evening between dinner and evening service. Singing extremely hearty; All familiar tunes. Practice for
fire
alarm for Collision.

JANUARY1915
Entry.4:
Lectured to men in morning, and to nurses and men in afternoon. Campbell discussed the question of changing guards from "ceremonial". Snapped officers playinghockey.

Passed "the Brothers" 30 miles to starboard in the afternoon, two high flat topped islets very similar in outline. Seaweed. Met several vessels &including one transport.
Entry.5:
Passed Cape Guardafuiat 7 a.m.
Passed
a steamer "Thermos" to starboard at 6 p.m. Never passed anything mobile before! Gave 3 lectures. Saw 2 feluccasto port this morning.
Entry.6:
Felucca to starboard 3 miles off at 7 a.m.

Aden 3 p.m. anchoring outside harbour & flying yellow flag, Big grey liner "Empress of Russia" anchored 1mile away. Stayed till 11 p.m. Repairing machinery.Left ½ an hour after the converted cruiser. Mountain behind Aden titanic. Moonrise beautiful. Lectured 
3
 4 times, Officers, Tasmanian nurses and men (twice).
Entry.7: Entered Bab-el-Mandeb by western side of Perim at 7 a.m. "Empress of Russia" and another converted cruiser "Himalaya" (P.&O.) watching the entrance & examining all vessels. "Liebenfels" a German prize from Bombay with cargo entering just behind us. Met 11 a.m. another converted cruiser "Empress of Asia" going South. Passed Jebel Hamar and lighthouse on Abu Ail at 5 p.m. Beautiful white just within the straits.Weather fine, cool.
Entry.8: Said to be 12 converted cruisers in the Red Sea. No other ships; sea, and no land all day.Lectured to Officers of C.H., nurses, & men.Weather warm. A lot of dragonflies came on board at night.
Entry.9: No sight of land or ships. Very rough wind (head) early this morning; roughest sea since Bass Straits. Lectured to Officers and men. Weather cold. Nausea for a while this morning; but had all my meals. Vaccination practically no result.
Entry.10:
Attended Church parade & evening prayers. Passed Daedalus shoal 1.45 p.m. Officer of the day.

JANUARY1915
Entry.11: Entered Gulf of Suez 7 a.m. desolate country on both sides. Arrived Suez 8 p.m. Doctor naval Military Officers came off. Finished letter home. Saw snow on mountain to the east of Gulf of Suez.
Entry.12: Saw a lot of letters fall into the sea; hope mine was not amongst them. Am Officer of the day (5th time). Left Suez & entered Canal 12.45 p.m., passing close to battleship Ocean. Indian troops lining the shores of Canal with trenches wire entanglements etc. Some troops along Canal near Ismalia saidthey were Australian Engineers. Heard the Turks were 2 days march from Ismailia. Arrived Port Said about 2 a.m. Coal & water.
Entry.13:
Went ashore for 2 hours. Left for
Alexandria
5 p.m. Colonel Martin went to Cairo for orders.
Entry.14: Arrived Alexandria 8 a.m. Pleasant weather. Probably all be landed here. Anchored. No shore leave today till 6 p.m. when 48 hours allowed to Senior officers. Tonight cold wind from the north west.
Entry.15:
Went ashore. Strange polyglot crowd, Egyptians, Italians, Greeks, Arabs, French, Jews, British. Went to Cook's, Pompey's Pillar, Catacombs, Canal to Cairo etc. U.S.S. Tennessee came in & anchored near us, landing 500 Jewish refugees from Turkey.
Many went trip to Cairo leaving ship at 6 a.m. & returning 11 p.m. Weather cold & windy.
Sent 3 post cards to mother (pictures) without writing
Entry.16: Showery morning. After lunch went by train to Ramleh & visited 1000 bed military hospital prepared for sick Indians from France. Orders out for disembarkation of all troops tomorrow.
Entry.17:
Ras el tin English Hospital and Indian Hospital again with Follitt & Kay; walk through town. Lunch at Star of Italy restaurant Toussoun Pasha Street; tea at Piccadily tea rooms.

JANUARY1915
Entry.18:
On ship all day. Col. Giblin called to Cairo tonight & took Campbell, Capt.Col Bryant & Major Powell also called & went. Expect orders to entrain in the morning. All equipment ashore except 2 motor cars.
P.&.O. boat with wounded Indians? arrived here.
Advance party of No 2 GeneralHospital went to Cairo.
Entry.19:
On ship all day. Another advance party of No 2 General Hospital went to Cairo. No word from Giblin; but Boddam got wire from Campbell– "Nothing doing yet."
Have got a cold, otherwise well.
Entry.20: Officer of the day again– my 6th time! More than a fair share. No news from Giblin. Foggy morning; warm afternoon. On ship all day.
Entry.21:
On ship all day except for an hour when Follitt, Sutherland and I took a boat and photographed the Kyarra, Tennessee, the lighthouse and the Khedive's Palace.
Russell wrote on this date to me from Mount Morgan tellingthat the papers had announced the arrival of Kyarra at Alexandria.
Entry.22:
Went up to town and with Atkins took a (Garry?) to the Messa Gardens. Fourth rate! I saw some lantana and prickly pear there under cultivation! Drove there along bank of Mahmoudiyah Canal; back by another road. Found on returning to quay that the Kyarra had removed to a berth near the breakwater.
No 2 Genl. Hospl. to go to Cairo on Sunday.
Entry.23: Up town with Maclean. Visited Army Service Camp atGabbari (Men) and met Captains Willard and (the Vet) McKenna. Lunch at "Star of Italy." Heard on returning that Clearing Hospital goes to Cairo also tomorrow. Dinner at Khedivial Club with Giblin Campbell and Boddam 16 P.T. Drove back to ship, 7 piastres.
Entry.24:
To Cairo, arriving 12.40 p.m. Heliopolis 2 p.m. Officer of the day.



JANUARY1915
Entry.25: Lodged in palace of marble and granite. Immense place; cost£2 million pound to build and another million for fittings. Walked to new camp forming at aerodrome for new forces arrived from Australia shortly. Magnificent small new city built on the desert.
Entry.26:
Train to Cairo in afternoon. Saw Shepheards & Grand Continental. Had a lemon squash with Carlile at latter. Col Giblin came in in motor to see about news just to hand that ½ Hospl. to go to Canal. Later news says whole Hospital to go, also 21 nurses and the No 1 Stationary Hospital.
Began our own mess today; very satisfactory. Off tomorrow to the front!
Entry.27:
Left Palace of Koubbeh Railway Station (Heliopolis) 3.30 p.m., Cairo 4.45 pm. All Clearing Hospital,
½
No 1 staying and 21+7 nurses. Left Major Powell & his lot as Ismailia. Arrived Port Said 12.15 a.m. without any adventures. Saw H.M.S. Swiftsure & 1 or 2 others in the Canal; also a big camp at Ismailia & others along the bank, also a lot of camels. 
Detrained
 7 a.m. of
Entry.28:
detrained. Went in cabs to Eastern Exchange Hotel. Nurses to the Hospital.

28 Thursday
Took up quarters in a school for young orphans taught by French nuns (and 1 Irish one) opposite Jardin de Lesseps and the fine Catholic Church. Went to the aviator's funeral as far as the church. Had 10stretchers made up as beds in one big room. Meals & Bed in Hotel. Are evidently to act as a base Hospital. Saw Indian Hospital.
New address Asile Condreux. Port Said.
Set up 1 large room full of stetchers with sheets etc
Entry.29:
Busy
settin
clearing out rooms & setting up beds, instead of stretchers. Gave directions for number and location of lights in all rooms etc. Bed & meals at Eastern Exchange Hotel. Saw seaplanes yesterday & today ­­­– Officers quartered in nuns' cells. Mine St Marie de St. Imelda's! Nuns are of order of Le bon pasteur.
Entry.30: Saw 8 big Australian transports anchor here. Went on board the A30 and saw Major Croll & D'Arcy Hetherington. Also saw on A32 Herbert McLaughlin, Jock Orr & many other Mount Morganites. Took 17 of our Indian wounded & 1 wounded Turk from Railway Station to English Hospital in Ambulance.
Entry.31:
Visited Government Hospital to see Sick Australian landed yesterday.
Slept on board S.S. Aenne Rickmers german prize, Capt Haskell, am under orders of Capt Weldon Intelligence Dep.

FEBRUARY1915
Entry.32:
Left Port Said 6 a.m. Passed El Galos & El Arish & Gaza. Landed a man between Gaza & Askelon a Bedouin. Waited off shore till 3.30 a.m. of Tuesday for return of Capt Weldon & party, since 11 p.m. Not far from Jerusalem now! – 45 miles only Two 
fl
 other flyers aboard, Hillas & Paul, & 2seaplanes.
Saw boy with broken arm. Hillas sore chin Weldon cough.
Entry.33:
Came back to Coast off El 
T
 Arish. 3 Flights by Hillas & Paul, planes not able to rise high enough to go inland one caught fire on starting & was slightly damaged & had to return – easily repaired. Got several snaps of planes. Inspected ship. Quarters & men’s closets dirty.
Coast line low; Hills behind El Arish. 
Inspected ship
 Patients – boy with broken arm and man with corneal ulcer. Paul Otorrhea Hillas.
Entry.34:
Too windy for any flying, & sea too rough for planes to be launched. Dodged about off El 
T
 Arish all day. Could see the town & a tall minaret about 3 miles off. Late in afternoon saw H.M.S. Doris closely examining the coast inshore of us. She passed us just before dark.
Patients, corneal ulcer, Paul, Hillas, Captain.
Entry.35:
Doris passed us again during night. Cruised slowly about all day out of sight of land. Too rough to launch the seaplanes, or to take off the men 
from
 near Gaza.
Patients, corneal ulcer Hillas, Captain.
Entry.36: Dodging about off El Arish all day. Sea too rough for launching planes.
Entry.37: Paul made flight S.E. from El Arish to Mowellah and Kosseima, nothing much seen. Hillas’ machine rose with difficulty, reexamined on ship & fault remedied; then rose again, until stopped by rain.
Entry.38:
Paul made successful reconnaissance over Beersheba & saw about 20,000 troops. Then flew to near Hebron, but couldn’t get enough altitude to go over Hebron. Very successful flight.

My birthday also A. Cintré.
Entry.39: Met S.S. Rabenfels, another German prize ship off El Arish. Captains Todd and Herbert and a French “pilote” came off to us in a boat. They are to take up our work whilst the Aenne Rickmers goes into dock at Alexandria to be cleaned. Left for Port Said.
Entry.40:
Arrived at Port Said 8.30 a.m. after a very interesting trip. Landed 
at
 and reported at AsileCouvreux and at Military Headquarters. Major Newland of 1st. Australian Stationary Hospital at Ismailia visited us at night. No casualties been admitted into our Hospital during my absence. Giblin has done an appendectomy & Gordon a hernia during my absence. Nothing else. Found 3 of our men in med ward, slight ailments Got letter from Mother dated
Entry.41:
10 Wednesday
Giblin & Gordon went to see the battlefield. Genl. Williams visited our Hospital during forenoon. Yesterday I found letters frm Major Jackson & Cap Follit & Pte Polssonwaiting for me. Jackson been treated badly.
Entry.42:
Walked to end of breakwater.
Got I.O.U. from Giblin for 21.16.11 balance of pay due to him of embarkation, and signed receipt for samein acquittance roll. (Got 600 piastres from him about 2 weeks ago, in notes.)
Entry.43:
Walked through Arab quarter, took photos. Got 300 piastres.
(Got 300 piastres from Giblin,) Got a letter from Smithson.
Entry.44:
Walked with Lieut Carlile through native quarter and out to our Camp near Railway Station.
Only 1 man in medical wards
Entry.46:
Last 2 nurses returned Heliopolis.
Hospital dismantled & equipment packed. Mrs. Croll had gone on a visit to Cairo, and did not return here.
Entry.47:
Waiting orders to return.
Donald Mackenzie called. Was in Port Said looking for lost equipment. Went to see him at Hotel after dinner.
Entry.48: Still waiting. Mackenzie returned to Cairo.
Entry.49:
Still waiting. Got word this morning to send an advance party to Cairo, 1 Officer & 20 others; also 1 officer, 1 N.C.O., dispenser & 8 men to be detailed to go to Australia on transport Suffolk in charge of invalids. Captain O’Brien to lead1st. party; Lieut Carlile the party to Australia. Major Gordon’s birthday, entertained the officers at dinner at Eastern Exchange Hotel.
Went to say Goodbye to Sr Masie Malachy.
Entry.50: Completely removed all traces of the AsileCouvreux as a Hospital. French Consul turns out to be business manager of the nuns, & is very annoyed at our going so soon. Wants £200, building in statu quo. Contractor’s bill is well over £200 also.
Entry.51: Moved out to our Camp near Railway station on the sand
Entry.52:
Left Port Said 12.30 p.m., arrived Cairo 4.30. Trainto Base details Camp Abbassia between Cairo & Heliopolis in Base details Camp.

FEBRUARY1915
Entry.53:
Met Captain Kenerie here Quartermaster of Camp. Very pleased to meet. Went into Cairo in afternoon and came back by trainto Abbassia Station & then walked.
10th A.S.C. from Alexandria is in Camp here under Major Smith.

23 Tuesday
Went to aerodrome in morning & met Jackson, Foxton, Kay, Col Cannon, Major Carter, Luther, Willis, Frank Moran, & Lt. Harvie. Had lunch at Shepheards (24 PT ) & went to Mena Camp in afternoon, Saw Col Sutton, Major Read, Cap Fletcher & the Pyramids. Motor car both ways with Campbell & Boddam. Recd. from Col Giblin 500 P.T. to
Entry.54:
24 Wednesday
Visited Citadel and Mosque Mehemet Ali in a.m. bought chair, bath, bucket and lantern. Visited native bazaars in afternoon. With Giblin & Mattei. Heliopolis in evg, Jackson, McLean, etc.. Met Graham Butler, Major Butler, Cap Goldsmith etc.

25 Thursday
About the Camp. Went to Heliopolis in evening & had yarn with Jackson McLean.
Recd. from Col Giblin 183 P.T. being with the 500 recd. on 23rd one fortnight’s pay. Also received 683 P.T. another fortnight’s pay. Am paid up now to
Entry.55: And have drawn 600 + 300 PT against the £28 owing to me at date of disembarkation,
Entry.57:
News came to be ready to go on on Sunday next.
Giblin paid me a cheque for 
1130
 Piastres + cash thus redeeming his I.O.U. for balance of my back pay. No pay due now, except current pay.
Entry.58:
Went into Cairo and changed cheque for 1130 PT at Anglo Egyptian Bank.
Selected another horse in place of Brown mare. Bay Gelding (2–122)
Letter from Russell dated
Entry.60:
“Standing fast”. Rode to Heliopolis and said Goodbye to McLean, Syme, Jackson etc.

MARCH1915
Entry.61:
Rode out the Suez Road and through the Aerodrome Camp. Returned 1.15 p.m. and found orders for entraining had come for C.H. 5.15. Entrained at Abbassia in 2 sections; made up train at Cairo. Left Cairo 7 p.m. Arrived Alexandria 12 midnight.
Left my big trunk at Cook’s Cairo, – to be sent for when required.
Entry.62:
On board B.I.S.S. Malda. Other units already aboard No 3. Field Amb, under Col Sutton, No 4 A.S.C. 3 other transports went out. Saw Devanka with Major Stewart as S.M.O. aboard pull out. Also saw Ionian off; Suffolk went in the night. All entrain Infantry exceptions.
Went up to town in afternoon & photographed Mehemet Ali & had a look at the Scotch Church. Posted book of views of Alex to Mother; bought 2 rolls of films.
Entry.63:
No I. A Stationary H arrived at breakfast time, & embarked at once. Ship left Alexandria 2 p.m. heading North by West. Lemnos said to be our destination. There is a Field Bakery & Field Butchery on board. Ship’s position at noon is “To Randeliusa Id. 129.
Position 34.34N,23.10E.Run 218 miles Noon
Entry.64:
4 Thursday
Sea calm. Only one engine running.
Sighted land on port bow about 3 p.m. – Karpathos; Passed it in the evening. For position see entry last page, bottom.(At noon 34.34N,23.10E)
Entry.65: At 8 a.m. Patmos was abeam to starboard and we later passed close to Nicaria on starboard; other islands to port.Position at noon,37.41N, 25.49E.To Lemnos 136.Distance run 223. Sea calm. Went “slow” from 1 p.m.Passed Khios at dusk.
Entry.66:
Entered Mudros Bay, Lemnos Id. , & anchored 7.25 a.m. 5 others transports at anchor, – Suffolk, Devanka, Ionian Condor Castle & Nizam all containing Australians except which has Territorials (or Regulars). 33 vessels in the bay; 3 big warships, severalsmall ones, destroyers & submarines, including the Australian A.E.2. Shores of bay beautifully green & cultivated. Harbour landlocked, (and 
Greek
?) Several heavily laden Colliers here.
This is our advanced base.
Posted letter to mother – goes via Malta; (Egyn. stamp).

7 Sunday
Route
Entry.67:
miles. I led the C.H. through Mudros. Another transport arrived during night, 6 mine sweepers during the day.

MARCH1915
Entry.68:
H.M.S. Lord Nelson came in this morning. She was in action yesterday in Dardanelles & got a shot below water line. Several other warships came in & went out. Read Kipling’s Jungle book.
Tent amb division went on shore from3rdField Amb under Major Butler.
Entry.69:
A Messageries liner came in early & anchored amongst the warships near the entrance.
All troops on Malda landed & had route march for 6 miles. Troops from other ships landed, 3rd. Brigade. Returning we all climbed up a rope ladder to ship. When on shore visited Telanea & another village, Varos.
Entry.70:
Cold misty day, 200 landing, as there was a strong south wind, too rough for boats.
Queen Elizabeth in the Bay.
Entry.71: Bright sunny day. Landed at Point, & walked 9 miles, saw north & east boundaries of Island, Mt. Athos, Thrasos, Samothraki (all snow capped), Imbros & both sides of Dardanelles. Saw larks, molehills, & myosotis (forget-me-not) marguerites, & crater of old volcano (cultivated). Met Med Off of Marines who landed last week at the Dardanelles & got cut up – lost 40 out of 250.
Entry.72: Landed on West of Bay & marched 8 miles. Wild thyme, magenta ranunculus. Passed through very old village of Sapi. “Ef Karisto” = “Thank you”. “Kali mari” = “good day”. Re-embarked at Portianos pier, 42 big ships in the bay, including 26 transports, 1 of which is the Franconia, Cunarder 18,000 tons. 5 transports one French. Some French warships and a Russian. Oil tank, Colliers, Queen Elizabeth, Indefatigable, Triumph, Sudan (Red Cross) etc
Entry.73:
Rowed an oar to H.M.S. Queen Elizabeth, 8 & 15” guns etc. and boarded Aenne Rickmers, which was torpedoed at 2 a.m. in Gulf of Smyrna 2 nights ago. Big hole in starboard bow. Captain Gaskell, Captain Weldon & Lieut Paul also “Ginger” Chief engineer still on board. McWhae, Prior, Conrick, Carlile & Ford with me. All very pleased to see me.
I rowed 6 miles.
Swiftsure& Euryalus & Dublin & other ships here.

14 Sunday
Rowed to Annie Rickmers 2 miles – only Gaskell aboard examined result of explosion.

MARCH1915

15 Monday
Route
Entry.74: miles, I led the Cl H home. The 3rd brigade (3000-4000 Infantry).
Entry.75: Field Ambulance, Clearing Hospital. Most of war ships gone out of harbour. Queen Elizabeth went yesterday. Campbell insubordinate. Found that the Annie Rickmers people had called on me in my absence and left a card.
Entry.76: Rowed to Annie Rickmers 2 miles & photographed the hole in her bows, outside & inside. McWhae & I asked them to dinner. Couldn’t come.Spoke to Giblin about Campbell’s conduct. G. said that C. had already discussed the “incident” with him. I said it was impertinence on C’s part to do so; and asked G. to warn C. that under similar circs I would place C under arrest.
Entry.77:
–

17 Wednesday
 18 Thurs
Walked to Mudross with Capt Atkins and bought some coloured handkerchiefs. Saw a lot of bright uniformed Frenchmen. Saw our horses looking well. Weather stormy. 5 Castle Line transports full of troops left suddenly this afternoon. General Ian Hamilton said to have arrived today.
 Walked 6 miles. Saw Polsson? my old 
Sergt
 Corporal Clerk, in 9th Infry.
Entry.78:
19 Friday
Marched 10 miles, including visit to northern harbour. Saw Greek church built on site of some old ruin; pieces of marble and scraps of pottery about – ancient Greek.
Weather rough. Mail leaving here. Some of Castle liners returned.
Major Butler of Hobart has daughter of Fred Brewer as nurse to his children.
Entry.79:
20 Saturday
Blowing a “full gale”, S.W.; strength “8 or 9”.
Ship snagged her anchors, & had to take up a fresh position. Many boats of other ships littering the beach. Vessel under easy steam all day to ease strain on anchors.
Gale from S.W.
Entry.80:
21 Sun
Calm morning, several torpedo boats came in this morning. Heard bad news – that Irresistible & Ocean & a French cruiser 
had
 has been sunk in the Dardanelles & another French cruiser disabled, & the Indefatigable had to be beached on Tenedos. All lives lost on F cruiser. Wind increased to gale in evening from N.E. with rain. Cold. 1st Stationary Hospital said to be about to reembark. Rumour that we must all be ready to leave the Island in six days.
No service on ship – Weather too rough for Chaplain.
Entry.82:
On ship. Bay rough. Reports of movements to take place affecting units on ship.
Queen Elizabeth & Dublin returned here from Dardanelles; former being hit herself one shot going through a funnel.
Field Bakery to go on shore.
Entry.83:
C H received orders to tranship to Gloucester Castle, but no barges were sent. So Gloucester Castle put to sea without us.
Several transports arrived, and most of the Castle liner transports departed.
Read Ruskin’s Crown of Wild Olive and Cestus of Aglaia.
Sent a sovereign to Haswell per Boddam.
Entry.84: Went with Giblin on board Dunluce Castle & met General McGrigor in Command of the base, Col Maher D.D.M.S., Major Thom & Capt Gilmour. Sea too rough to return, so went in tow to Mudros landed, walked up town & to Stationary Hospital, & rowed back to Malda in evening when sea calmed.
Entry.85:
Strong cold northerly wind & rough sea all day. Nothing doing. Did some practice with semaphore and dealt with Sergt. Remington and a man for smoking on horse deck.
Read Barrie’s Auld Licht Idylls .
Sent post cards to Alec & Jess & to Major Maclean.
Entry.86:
On ship waiting for orders. Most of ships gone out of harbour. French transports re-embarking horses. Capt Mattei left C H exchanging with Corbin of 1 A S H.
Sea calm. Bakery and Butchery sections left ships for the shore. Heard news of fall of Przemysl; and of second attack on Suez Canal by the Turks.
Read the Golden Book of Marcus Aurelius, and did semaphore with Colonel Sutton.
Entry.87:
Landed with C H for practice in hill climbing, but were recalled at once, owing to threatening weather.
Marcus Aurelius. Semaphore with Sutton.

28 Sunday
Landed & chose site for camp. Church service by Archdeacon Richards of Zeehan.
5 weeks’ pay due to me.
Entry.89:
C H landed & did some tent pitching. Officers went for a ride through Rosopol. Inflexible here from Tenedos; 21 bodies were found today in one of her watertight compartments. She has two tripod masts. Queen Elizabeth still here. German Seaplane reported to have dropped bombs on Tenedos Island.
Aenne Rickmers still here, with seaplanes on board.
Entry.90:
Stormy day; strong wind from SE. No landing.
Read R.L. Stevenson, & did semaphore.
Hostile aeroplane seen early this morning by several, over northern side of Island.
Entry.91:
Got men on to making a Gihon’s cot on a stretcher.
Big mail arrived from Egypt. No letters for me or for Clearing Hospital; so read Index to Johnston’s Atlas whilst others were reading their letters.
On ship all day. Other officers went for a ride.

APRIL1915
Entry.92:
Landed, and rode to Mudros and Rosopolsaw many wild ranunculi and butter cups.
Boarded the Soudan, Hospital ship. She took the wounded from the Dardanelles to Malta recently (140). Inflexible, Queen Eliz Triumph & 4 or 5 other big ships here still. Also Aenne Rickmers, Colliers, supply ships, and the transports of Australians only
Entry.93:
Service on board. Did censoring all day. Wrote to G.A.R. and mother & cards to Jessie.
Finished modifying stretcher into a Gihon’s ambulance cot.
Entry.94:
Sports in afternoon; Concert at night.
6 weeks pay due to me.
Entry.95:
Rode to Kastron with Giblin, Gordon, Corbin, Campbell & Boddam. 30 miles. Called on Commandant.
Ship shifted her anchorage nearer mouth of harbour.

APRIL1915
Entry.96:
Very cold windy day. Did not leave ship, Nizam is tied up alongside.
Read Kipling ­­­– The light that failed. Read also 2 old 
Queenslanders
Capricornians& 2 old Morning Bulletins – from Pte Brighton.
Entry.97:
Horses embarked on Nizam & Wagons transhipped to Nizam from Malda. Several battleships went out of harbour. Aenne Rickmers drifted ashore during the night. Yesterday 3 launches 
were
 foundered in the Bay. 3 F.A. to go to Nizam except Bearer Division which goes to Ionian. Heard we are to go to Ionian tomorrow & horses to go to Suffolk.
On ship all day.
Entry.98:
Transferred to the Ionian (Allan line). Weather warm and fine. Saw Samothraki covered with snow again; ditto Athos.
An Australian troopship (the third today) came in just before dark, her men cheering loudly as she came opposite us. Met Major Stokes and many others.

8 Thursday
Went ashore for a couple of hours & bought 62 lbs of charcoal, the unit owes
Entry.99: for it. Several Australian transports arrived crowded & cheering. Said to be 175 transports and 200,000 troops to come. Steamer Virginia flying American flag was siezed by Canopus and brought here. Said to have guns and ammunition for Turks and Turkish Officers aboard. She is being unloaded into lighters. Very few warships here, but harbour filling up with transports & water & oil ships.
Entry.100:
Mail arrived here last night by transports from Alexandria. Sorted on Malwa, now the Headquarters boat. Our post(Ionian) contained 17 letters for me & 4 bundles newspapers 3 parcels books & 1 parcel B.M.J’s . Also a cable for me from Russell, posted from Egypt ­­­– “Major Richards Australian Clearing Hospital, Egypt, Passed leaving Malwa England exceptional advantages. Richards.” What does the latter part mean? I am so pleased he has passed.
Wrote to mother before I got most of my letters as there was a mail going out this afternoon. May God comfort my wife with husband and “baby” both so far away.
Entry.101: Wrote to Mother & Jessie & Russell & Mrs. Croll & Mrs. Butler. PC’s to Russ, Alec, Mrs. Lyle, Lillie, Read all my letters over several times.
Entry.102: Saw all over the Queen Elizabeth, the biggest warship afloat. 8 x 15 inch guns, shells weigh 1920 lbs. . Several other big transports came into harbour. Queen Elizabeth is 600 feet long & draws 34 feet.
Entry.103:
Col Giblin went ashore with some of the men & went routemarch to the north of the Island.
I fear Russell may have accepted an appointment in the R.A.M.C. which is likely to mean a Regimental Medical Officership in France. May God protect our boy against mutilation or death.
Entry.104:
Many transports coming in 
for
 for several days past; berthing in pairs. Harbour very full.
On ship all day.
Wrote another post card to Russell in case letter went astray ­­­– addressed P.& O’s S.S. Malwa Port Said Egypt 
Urgent
​.

14 Wednesday
Unit ordered to pack kitbags for transfer per 
to
 “Osmanich” to the Base.
Pontoons made by Engineers.
Lecture by Colonel Weir C.O. of 10th Battalion, in the Gallipoli peninsula, giving proposed landing place of
Entry.105:
Brigade & giving details of defensive preparations on land.
On ship all day.
Entry.106:
On ship all day. Rearranging my baggage. Heard 
from D.A.D.M.S.
 that the C.H. is to be converted into a bearer division and to land on Gallipoli peninsula with the covering party, making the beginning of the land attack to capture the ports. Volunteered to lead, if there is to be a separate bearer division. In that case, will land on the first day. Have asked O’Brien, Atkins & Carlyle (all agreed). We will be in the thick of it.

16 Friday
Heard we are to be taken on board cruisers and destroyers to Gallipoli Peninsular & then transferred to Barges and towed ashore. 2 Companies from 10th Battalion went on board the “Prince of Wales” this evening, fully armed, for practise for
Entry.107: 3 hours, then returned to Ionian. Engineers also went. Heard a Turkish destroyer which escaped from Dardanelles some week or 2 ago, had attacked a transport & fired 3 torpedoes at her at 100 yards, all missing; destroyer sunk by Minerva.
Entry.108: Ionian moved away from Suffolk, and anchored just inside boom at mouth of harbour. Heard that a Turkish destroyer had fired 4 torpedoes at a transport and missed with all; but that 60 to 100 men had been lost through one boat falling on another when men in alarm were taking to the boats. Giblin & Corbin to be in advance party; not Carlyle.
Entry.109:
Captive balloon, seaplane, submarines & destroyers all very busy about mouth of harbour.
Agamemnon near us has her hind funnel badly wrecked & shrapnel holes in fore funnel.





APRIL1915
Entry.110: Service on board last night by Rev McPhee. "A few more years", "Nearer my God", "O heavenly father". Communion, of which I partook.
